title: Deflated U.K. Country House Prices Draw in Eager Londoners
text:
Affluent Londoners, attracted by deflated home values, are driving house sales in the British countryside, according to a report Friday from London-based estate agency Knight Frank.



The average sale price for a prime country home fell 1.7% in the third quarter compared to a year ago, a slight improvement over the second quarter when prices fell by an annual rate of 2.3%, according to the index. Sales prices have now been falling steadily for over a year and are roughly 6% lower than they were at the time of the Brexit referendum in 2016, by Knight Frank’s measure.

Home values in the British countryside look even more attractive when compared to a decade ago. Prices never fully recovered from the global financial crisis, meaning the average prime country home is now trading roughly 20% below its 2008 peak price, according to the index.



Those discounts appear to be drawing in city-dwellers, who can stretch their budgets across many more square feet when buying outside of the U.K. capital. So far this year, Londoners accounted for more than one in three deals over £2 million (US$2.53 million) in the countryside, the highest that number’s been in eight years, according to Knight Frank.



Interest in luxury country homes is likely to persist, and help stabilize price declines in some areas, according to Knight Frank—which says the number of house hunters with a budget of £2 million or more has risen 9% compared to last year.

The only hitch for luxury home buyers at the moment is that some of the best homes may be sitting on the sidelines, as would-be sellers “hesitate due to the political uncertainty,” said Oliver Knight, associate at Knight Frank, adding that softness in country home prices will likely persist for the remainder of the year and into 2020.
